snippet: Scientists have discovered fossils of fleas 10 times the size of modern counterparts, with elongated, sharp mouth parts that may have allowed them to feed on dinosaurs.
abstract: Diying Huang study in journal Nature reports the discovery of fossils of the world's oldest known fleas, which lived during the Early Cretaceous period; fleas grew to a relatively giant length of half of an inch, and may have subsisted on the blood of dinosaurs rather than mammals.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered fossils of fleas 10 times the size of modern counterparts, with elongated, sharp mouth parts that may have allowed them to feed on dinosaurs.

headline.print_headline: Giant Jurassic Fleas Packed a Mean Mouth
headline.seo: Giant Jurassic Fleas Packed a Mean Mouth
headline.main: Giant Jurassic Fleas Packed a Mean Mouth
